8.32.text:
Let me tell you how proud I am to stand before
you the first Conservative Chancellor in a

15.17.text:
Conservative Government to address a Conservative
Conference in eighteen years.

22.54.text:
If I’d told you twelve months ago that the
Member of Parliament for Morley and Outwood

32.64.text:
was going to come onto this stage and speak
in our economy debate you’d have called

39.84.text:
security.
Andrea, your win capped off a night that no-one

44.87.text:
here will ever forget.
Can you all remember where you were when that

56.29.text:
exit poll came through?
I certainly can.

61.01.text:
I was just a few miles away from here, waiting
to go to my count at the Macclesfield leisure

69.20.text:
No I wasn’t.
I was completely nervous.

72.97.text:
Unable to sit down.
Unable to stand still.

75.46.text:
I was pacing around.
And then a moment of calm did descend.

81.30.text:
I realised there was absolutely nothing more
I could do.

86.93.text:
I was powerless.
Completely powerless in the face of the real

91.99.text:
power of the British people.
You realise, the way we talk about these elections

97.52.text:
is all wrong.
We think elections are the moment when we

100.91.text:
all go round the country and talk to people.
But actually elections are when the British

106.24.text:
people talk to us.
And what the British people said to us in

110.92.text:
May couldn’t have been clearer:
We elect you to do a job.

116.87.text:
So take decisions, don’t duck them.
And the truth is this:

122.75.text:
If you do take those decisions - even if the
decisions are unpopular and bitterly opposed

129.04.text:
at the time -
If you do take the decisions and they are

132.68.text:
rooted in your values and turn out to be the
right ones, then people will go on putting

137.41.text:
their trust in you.
That’s the lesson of the last Parliament.

142.34.text:
That’s the lesson for this one.
So we’ve had our instructions from the British

147.22.text:
people and we say to them:
we will not let you down.

160.79.text:
You in this hall are the heroes of this famous
campaign.

165.41.text:
You’re the ones who fought inch by inch,
door by door, street by street for this election

174.17.text:
A great team, I’m lucky to count myself
part of.

178.08.text:
I want to thank you.
I want to thank you on behalf of every candidate

181.63.text:
who stood in this election.
And I’ve been asked to pass on a special

185.68.text:
thanks.
From the maintenance team at Downing Street.

189.06.text:
They want to thank you that they don’t have
to put up an eight-foot high tombstone in

192.39.text:
the back garden.
I want to thank my brilliant Treasury team:

211.20.text:
and the world class economist Jim O’Neill.
And there’s one member of the Conservative

217.36.text:
team who I personally owe a huge amount to.
Let’s face it.

222.80.text:
There were moments when lots of people had
doubts whether our plans would work moments,

229.58.text:
as I was well aware, when people had doubts
about me.

234.53.text:
But one person always backed me in private
and in public, and never wavered in their

240.10.text:
support.
I want to thank him.

241.70.text:
That is the person who’s led our country
with integrity, intelligence and imagination.

247.22.text:
My friend, our Prime Minister: David Cameron.
Under David’s leadership, after a full term

273.71.text:
in Government we increased both the number
seats we hold and the share of the vote we

279.09.text:
won.
That’s a winning combination no Prime Minister

283.36.text:
of any party has achieved since the nineteenth
century.

288.58.text:
It earns David not just a mandate to govern;
It earns him a place in the very highest rank

294.39.text:
of our party’s leadership.
David, we salute you.

304.72.text:
But, friends, it is precisely in our hour
of greatest success that I choose to come

317.64.text:
here to deliver a warning.
A warning for us all to heed.

322.28.text:
It is this:
Don’t let us rest on our laurels.

326.34.text:
The British people have not put us here to
congratulate ourselves.

329.66.text:
They have put us here to do a job.
The lesson of the last five years, and the

334.96.text:
victory that followed, is that the future
favours the bold.

338.62.text:
So we’ve got to be the builders, the people
with the new ideas.

343.08.text:
The people open to the new thinking.
Ready to listen.

347.10.text:
Admit where we get it wrong.
Accept when others have got it right.

351.30.text:
The people with the plan for the future.
Some stand on the sidelines.

356.09.text:
Some want to knock things down.
But we – we are the builders.

363.67.text:
And let me tell you who we are building for.
The working people of Britain.

373.53.text:
The millions of people who work hard, provide
for their families and pay their taxes for

379.09.text:
the public services we need.
The people who just get on with it.

383.63.text:
They don’t have a trade union calling them
out on strike;

387.12.text:
there’s no pressure group that will go on
the radio to fight their cause.

391.06.text:
These are the people we’re fighting for.
Millions of working people.

395.45.text:
These people need to know we are on their
side.

407.65.text:
Because many of them, let’s be frank, still
voted for the Labour Party just this May.

414.87.text:
They want security and opportunity, but they
didn’t quite feel able to put their trust

420.43.text:
in us.
We’ve got to understand their reservations.

424.76.text:
So to these working people who have been completely
abandoned by a party heading off to the fringes

431.45.text:
of the left let us all here today extend our
hand.

436.68.text:
Do you know what the supporters of the new
Labour leadership now call anyone who believes

444.33.text:
in strong national defence, a market economy,
and the country living within its means?

450.32.text:
They call them Tories.
Well, it’s our job to make sure they’re

454.26.text:
absolutely right.
Because we’re now the party of work, the

468.92.text:
only true party of labour.
My message to today’s Labour Party is this:

474.49.text:
You head back to the 1980s.
We’re heading forward.

478.08.text:
You listen to the few.
We’ll govern for the many.

491.19.text:
Now I often get asked in this job: do you
understand the impact of the decisions you

498.49.text:
make?
And my response is this.

501.57.text:
Yes I do.
Because we’ve made decisions, there are

505.48.text:
a record number of people in work.
And let me tell you, if you don’t make decisions,

511.46.text:
then people do suffer.
And let me tell you this as well.

515.80.text:
Failing to run a sound economic policy is
the most unkind, uncaring thing a Government

522.40.text:
can do.
I’ll tell you what happens when you lose

524.81.text:
control of the public finances and borrow
money you don’t have.

528.80.text:
It’s not the richest who suffer, or the
trade union barons who lose their jobs.

533.49.text:
No, it’s always the poorest who suffer when
the economy fails.

536.71.text:
It’s always working families who lose their
jobs.

539.74.text:
That’s not a kinder, caring Britain.
I’ll tell you what that is.

543.17.text:
Its economic cruelty dressed up as socialist
compassion.

546.08.text:
And we’re not going to let them wreck the
lives of working people again.

564.27.text:
We are the builders.
And to build, you must build on solid foundations.

569.19.text:
We’ve laid those foundations these last
five years.

572.89.text:
We’ve established the idea that government
can’t go on spending money it hasn’t got.

578.63.text:
The idea that businesses need to be competitive
and make profits to create jobs.

583.38.text:
The idea that you don’t show your compassion
by the size of the benefit cheque you dole

588.17.text:
out, rather you get people back to work.
That’s what we built together.

594.47.text:
Every argument we won, another business started…
… another person got a job…

599.61.text:
… another academy school opened…
… another family felt the security of work.

604.73.text:
Every argument we won, we have shifted the
terms of the debate in our country and created

609.59.text:
a new centre ground, around fiscal responsibility
and lower welfare, reformed public services

615.83.text:
and support for business too.
We turned our country around, and together

620.75.text:
we’ve made sure, Britain is working again.
Now we must build on those foundations.

636.76.text:
Create the budget surplus.
Deliver lower welfare, lower taxes and higher

642.21.text:
wages.
Build the new roads, and railways, and runways.

645.46.text:
Win reform in Europe and put the power into
the Northern Powerhouse.

649.88.text:
To borrow from an American President, we choose
to take on these things not because they’re

656.13.text:
easy, but because they’re hard.
For we are the builders.

660.15.text:
And there are few things harder than repairing
the public finances.

666.02.text:
We are still spending much more as a country
than we raise.

670.53.text:
In the spending review this Autumn, we’ve
got to finish the job.

673.73.text:
And we’re going to do something more.
We’re going to make sure this country never

679.08.text:
gets into this mess again.
So we’re going to run a surplus.

683.98.text:
What that means is that in good years, we’ll
raise more than we spend and use the money

688.86.text:
to reduce our debts.
That way we’ll be better prepared when the

693.25.text:
storms come.
Because frankly, I look at the world at the

698.27.text:
moment and I see a lot of economic risk out
there.

702.37.text:
China is vital to our future, but it’s not
growing as strongly as it was;

707.50.text:
the Eurozone is still very weak;
and the latest jobs numbers from America are

713.72.text:
disappointing.
We can’t be immune from all of this. We

717.25.text:
must be prepared for whatever the world throws
at us.

721.32.text:
Our plan for a surplus provides security for
working people.

726.07.text:
We’re going to put it to a vote in the House
of Commons next week.

729.60.text:
And we’re going to go on fixing the roof
while the sun is shining.

736.90.text:
Part of fixing the roof is getting the British
taxpayer out of owning great chunks of the

748.81.text:
banking system.
I have this morning announced our plans to

752.37.text:
sell the remaining stake we have in Lloyds
bank.

756.31.text:
Next Spring, we will make Lloyds shares available
to every member of the public.

760.13.text:
They’ll be offered at a discount.
Small shareholders will get priority.

765.05.text:
And long-term investors will get a bonus.
You can register from today.

769.17.text:
It’s the biggest privatisation for more
than twenty years.

772.77.text:
And every penny we raise will be used to pay
off our debts.

786.56.text:
With Labour the banks went bust - we’re
fixing them.

789.36.text:
With Labour the debt soared - we’re going
to bring it down.

792.41.text:
Labour have now turned their back on opportunity
and aspiration - we’re going to build the

797.30.text:
share owning democracy this Party has always
believed in.

801.05.text:
Labour - the wreckers.
We are the builders.

805.04.text:
We’re going to have to do a lot more to
get Britain back into the black.

817.17.text:
I won’t pretend that making these cuts will
be easy.

820.92.text:
We’ve got to find more than £20bn of savings.
But I’ll tell you what I’m not prepared

826.96.text:
to do.
I’m not prepared to cut the NHS to balance

830.78.text:
the books.
We’ll make sure the health service has more

833.23.text:
money than ever before.
Some people question our commitment to the

844.08.text:
aid budget but with millions fleeing war zones,
and a crisis in Europe, I’m not prepared

850.03.text:
to cut it.
I want to spend our aid better so it helps

853.62.text:
the most vulnerable closer to their homes.
And because we’ve built a strong economy,

860.05.text:
here’s something else we can afford to do.
Invest in our national security and the armed

865.81.text:
forces who guarantee it - because this outward-facing,
internationally-confident, economically-sound

872.20.text:
nation - will renew our nuclear deterrent,
and spend 2% of our national income on the

877.40.text:
defence of the realm.
To deliver these priorities there will be

894.55.text:
tough choices this autumn.
But remember this when our opponents line

899.89.text:
up to fight for every borrowed pound of government
spending.

904.40.text:
The British people have heard the argument
that the deficit doesn’t matter and they’ve

909.85.text:
rejected it.
They’ve listened to politicians who forgot

912.98.text:
to mention the deficit, and they’ve rejected
them too.

917.99.text:
Now we’re told that instead of earning the
money we need to spend, the Bank of England

922.18.text:
can simply be told to print it.
What could be easier than that?

927.30.text:
We hear them say.
What could be easier than that?

930.05.text:
They said in Zimbabwe and Weimar Germany too.
It’s not monetarism - it’s magic money-tree-ism.

937.42.text:
And let me tell you messing around with the
independence of the Bank of England and letting

941.76.text:
inflation rip destroys savings and is a massive
risk to the economic security of every working

949.47.text:
family.
Mind you, I’d better be careful not to disagree

962.11.text:
with Jeremy Corbyn about absolutely everything
or else he’ll invite me to join his Shadow

966.56.text:
Cabinet.
Here’s another proposition we’re going

976.61.text:
to take on.
That Britain is condemned to be a low skill,

980.74.text:
low pay, high welfare economy.
I want the opposite. Lower welfare and higher

986.83.text:
pay.
The last time we brought our Conference here

989.71.text:
to Manchester, I slipped away from all the
fringe meetings and the receptions to see

995.08.text:
something that reminds me why I do this job.
Across the way, beyond the cordon, in a nearby

1001.78.text:
office block something uplifting was taking
place.

1005.72.text:
People at the job centre were signing up for
work.

1008.91.text:
I sat down with a group of them, young and
old, to talk to them about their futures.

1015.67.text:
They were nervy at first, they weren’t confident
about themselves because life had given them

1020.63.text:
precious few reasons for self-confidence.
But as we talked about their new jobs they

1026.87.text:
got more and more animated.
They were excited about their future and proud

1030.90.text:
to be in work.
Proud to have a job.

1033.96.text:
These are the people I’m fighting for.
Now we want to help these working people keep

1039.87.text:
more of what they earn.
We’ve raised the personal allowance, and

1043.76.text:
I’ll keep raising it again and again.
We’ve raised the threshold for the higher

1048.12.text:
rate and we’ll keep raising that too.
That’s what we’ve promised, that’s what

1052.64.text:
we’re delivering.
Lower income taxes for all and no income tax

1056.36.text:
for the lowest paid at all.
There’s another promise we made we’re

1070.92.text:
one nation.
Everyone makes a contribution.

1075.18.text:
No one gets something for nothing.
And that includes business.

1080.30.text:
So here’s the new settlement.
To business we say this…

1084.17.text:
… we’ll go on cutting your taxes…
… to the lowest rates of any major economy

1089.07.text:
in the world.
But in return, you have do more to train your

1093.08.text:
workforce and to pay higher wages.
And here’s the deal for working people - we

1098.24.text:
simply can’t subsidise incomes with ever-higher
welfare and tax credit bills the country can’t

1104.24.text:
afford.
But in return we’ll have:

1108.70.text:
and the new National Living Wage.
We’ve said it before, we’ll say it again:

1114.06.text:
Britain deserves a pay rise and with us, Britain
is getting a pay rise.

1121.63.text:
You know the National Living Wage is something
that should be welcomed across the political

1133.46.text:
divide.
I think it’s a great weakness of today’s

1137.44.text:
Labour Party that it can’t acknowledge any
good things done by Conservatives.

1143.04.text:
I’ll always pay tribute to the role the
Labour movement played in building the NHS

1149.37.text:
and establishing rights in the workplace.
But that sits alongside the equally proud

1155.25.text:
story of Conservative social justice.
The National Living Wage is the latest page

1161.67.text:
in that story.
For it was Conservatives in previous Governments

1166.28.text:
that ended the slave trade;
That stopped children working in factories

1170.35.text:
and gave them universal education;
That gave equal votes to women…

1174.92.text:
… and equal rights to disabled people.
Now it’s Conservatives in this government

1180.20.text:
that have banned modern slavery;
Legislated for gay marriage;

1184.60.text:
Given new shared employment rights to parents
and today extend them to grandparents too;

1189.33.text:
It’s now Conservatives in this Government
who are shining a light into the darkest corners

1194.43.text:
of our prisons and bringing the best education
to the poorest of our children.

1199.15.text:
So of course it’s this Conservative Government
that is introducing the National Living Wage.

1204.66.text:
A government for working people.
With a pay rise for six million of our citizens.

1210.26.text:
Building the society we promised where we
are all in this together.

1226.42.text:
But building doesn’t come easy.
Especially when it comes to new homes and

1231.47.text:
the infrastructure this country needs.
I am very lucky to represent a constituency

1238.00.text:
just a dozen miles to the south of here full
of pretty villages and market towns in the

1243.48.text:
flat and lush Cheshire plain.
The great writer Elizabeth Gaskell used to

1248.77.text:
live there, and she drew on her life in nineteenth
century Knutsford to write her most famous

1254.16.text:
book.
In the novel, Cranford, the town campaigns

1258.70.text:
to stop the new railway coming through.
And today, there are some people in my constituency

1264.85.text:
who want to stop our new high-speed railway.
I respect their opposition – but I also

1271.28.text:
respectfully disagree.
Where would Britain be if we had never built

1275.74.text:
railways or runways, power stations or new
homes?

1278.63.text:
Where will be in the future if we stop building
them now?

1282.50.text:
I’m not prepared to turn around to my children
or indeed anyone else’s child, and say:

1288.45.text:
I’m sorry, we didn’t build for you.
So here’s our plan.

1293.28.text:
First, we’re going to get many more homes
built for families to buy.

1297.71.text:
We’re sweeping away planning rules on brownfield
sites.

1301.32.text:
This autumn we’ll direct our housing budget
towards new homes for sale.

1306.86.text:
And we’ll give housing association tenants
the right to buy.

1310.21.text:
We’ve had enough of people who own their
own home lecturing others why they can’t

1317.11.text:
own one too.
I’m proud that we’re the ones giving more

1328.35.text:
than a million people the chance to have a
house of their own.

1332.02.text:
And if anyone wants to argue with us on that,
I say bring it on.

1335.83.text:
We’re going to build the home owning democracy
this Party has always stood for.

1341.82.text:
Second, we are going to find new ways to fund
the British infrastructure that drives our

1353.77.text:
productivity.
At the moment, we have 89 different local

1358.20.text:
government pension funds with 89 sets of fees
and costs.

1362.84.text:
It’s expensive and they invest little or
nothing in our infrastructure.

1367.93.text:
So I can tell you today we’re going to work
with councils to create instead half a dozen

1372.22.text:
British Wealth Funds spread across the country.
It will save hundreds of millions in costs,

1377.68.text:
and crucially they’ll invest billions in
the infrastructure of their regions.

1382.12.text:
And I’m increasing asset sales to ensure
we’re spending a greater proportion of our

1387.81.text:
national income on capital investment than
the last Labour government ever did.

1393.78.text:
Third, if we’re going to build, then we
have to shake Britain out of its inertia on

1405.10.text:
the projects that matter most.
There’s an idea, put forward by many people,

1410.57.text:
including some Labour politicians, and its
time has come.

1414.25.text:
An independent National Infrastructure Commission.
A Commission, set up in law, free from party

1420.37.text:
arguments, which works out…
… calmly and dispassionately what the country

1424.49.text:
needs to build for its future…
… and holds any Government’s feet to the

1428.29.text:
fire if it fails to deliver.
Like working with northern councils on how

1432.97.text:
we are going to make a reality of High Speed
3 the new link we want across the Northern

1437.21.text:
Powerhouse.
Like working with London on the next big public

1440.68.text:
transport projects after Crossrail, and how
we are going to fund them.

1444.56.text:
Like how we are going to make sure Britain
has the energy supplies it needs.

1448.31.text:
These are the first questions we set.
I’ve asked the new National Infrastructure

1452.36.text:
Commission to start its work today.
And I am delighted that the former Labour

1456.55.text:
Cabinet Minister and Transport Secretary Andrew
Adonis has agreed to be the Commission’s

1461.80.text:
first Chair.
He’ll now sit as a cross bench peer and

1465.30.text:
help us create Britain’s plan for the future.
Working together in the national interest.

1472.05.text:
Some stand on the sidelines.
Some want to knock things down.

1476.12.text:
We are the builders.
It’s because we’re not afraid to confront

1491.59.text:
the big issues that we’ve taken on reform
in the European Union.

1496.59.text:
I don’t want the continent that gave us
Isaac Newton and Leonardo da Vinci and Marie

1501.41.text:
Curie, to say we’ve given up on the future.
We joined the Common Market because it offered

1507.50.text:
us the promise of jobs and growth.
What it represents to many people across Europe

1513.08.text:
these days is unemployment and stagnation.
That must change.

1518.85.text:
We want the integrity of the single market,
but we don’t want to be part of the single

1522.66.text:
currency and as far as I’m concerned, Britain
never will be.

1527.89.text:
We want our neighbours to grow with us, but
we don’t want to be part of their ever-closer

1541.92.text:
Let’s achieve that.
Then as we promised we’ll put it to the

1544.92.text:
British people in the referendum – and let
the people decide.

1552.67.text:
There’s one other problem our country faces
that is so deep-seated, and so difficult that

1563.82.text:
no government has really tried to solve it
before.

1567.40.text:
And that’s the gap between north and south,
between London and the rest.

1571.84.text:
I grew up in the middle of London.
And l grew up with the cliché that if it

1577.64.text:
wasn’t happening in London then it wasn’t
happening at all.

1581.25.text:
Becoming an MP in the North of England has
changed me - made me realise that great as

1586.83.text:
our capital is - there is so much more to
this country.

1589.91.text:
And I’ve changed in the five years I’ve
done this job too.

1594.79.text:
I’ve always been able to see the problems
with government.

1598.27.text:
Now I understand too the power of government
to drive incredible, positive change.

1604.66.text:
I don’t want to do this job just to occupy
the office.

1607.37.text:
I’m here to make changes that last…
… solve problems to make people’s lives

1611.96.text:
better…
… slay dragons that stand in Britain’s

1615.32.text:
way.
That’s why I am so committed to the Northern

1619.11.text:
Powerhouse.
I’m throwing everything I’ve got at it.

1622.20.text:
I’ve brought new science here…
… promoted the arts here…

1625.32.text:
… backed transport links here…
… brought investment from places like China

1628.99.text:
here.
I don’t know if it will work.

1631.21.text:
But I do know that if you don’t even try
you’re bound to fail.

1634.54.text:
So I’m damn well going to try.
Let’s go and build that Northern Powerhouse.

1652.30.text:
In the end it all comes down to where the
power lies.

1655.82.text:
To who makes the decisions.
There’s a building, not too far from here

1661.97.text:
that reminds us of what local government used
to mean.

1665.11.text:
Look at Manchester Town Hall, in all its neo-gothic
splendour.

1669.45.text:
It was built as a place of power -a great
civic cathedral, where the decisions affecting

1676.22.text:
this city would be taken - not remitted to
a committee in London.

1680.20.text:
But over the decades, the wings of local government
were clipped again and again by all parties,

1686.03.text:
most especially ours.
Almost everything, from the amount they could

1690.08.text:
spend…
… to the taxes they could keep…

1692.02.text:
… to the work they undertook…
… was determined in Whitehall.

1695.32.text:
It’s time to face facts.
The way this country is run is broken.

1700.83.text:
People feel remote from decisions that affect
them.

1703.72.text:
Initiative is suffocated.
Our cities held back.

1706.68.text:
There’s no incentive to promote local enterprise.
It’s time we fixed it.

1711.84.text:
And I’ll work with anyone, from any political
party, to make that happen.

1716.61.text:
That’s why we’re devolving more power
to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

1722.50.text:
That’s why the people of Greater Manchester
will elect their first ever Mayor, in just

1727.99.text:
eighteen months’ time.
That’s why just last Friday we reached agreement

1733.04.text:
on a new elected mayor across the whole of
South Yorkshire.

1736.35.text:
We’re putting the power into the Northern
Powerhouse.

1741.79.text:
But we can go much, much further, here in
the north and around the country.

1751.11.text:
While everyone knows this country has to live
within its means - and that means savings

1755.86.text:
in local as well as national government - I
want to make sure that as we make these necessary

1760.98.text:
savings we use this moment to undertake far-reaching
reform.

1767.17.text:
Right now we have the merry go-round of clawing
back local taxes into the Treasury and handing

1772.85.text:
them out again in the form of a grant.
In my view, proud cities and counties should

1778.52.text:
not be forced to come to national government
with a begging bowl.

1783.15.text:
So I am announcing this:
Today I am embarking on the biggest transfer

1788.33.text:
of power to our local government in living
memory.

1790.79.text:
We’re going to allow local government to
keep the rates they collect from business.

1795.20.text:
That’s right, all £26bn of business rates
will be kept by councils instead of being

1808.67.text:
sent up to Whitehall.
Right now, we collect much more in business

1816.63.text:
rates than we give back in the main grant.
So we will phase out this local government

1821.04.text:
grant altogether.
But we will also give councils extra power

1825.78.text:
and responsibilities for running their communities.
The established transfers will be there on

1830.13.text:
day one, but thereafter, all the real growth
in revenue will be yours to keep.

1835.62.text:
So this is what our plan means.
Attract a business, and you attract more money.

1840.44.text:
Regenerate a high street, and you’ll reap
the benefits.

1843.31.text:
Grow your area, and you’ll grow your revenue
too.

1846.36.text:
And to help local people do that I want to
make another announcement today.

1850.80.text:
We’re going to abolish the 
uniform business rate entirely.

1864.45.text:
That’s the single, national tax rate we
impose on every council.

1869.01.text:
Any local area will be able to cut business
rates as much as they like…

1873.43.text:
…to win new jobs and generate wealth.
It’s up to them to judge whether they can

1877.99.text:
afford it.
It’s called having power and taking responsibility.

1883.65.text:
And for those big cities with elected mayors,
like London, Manchester and now Sheffield,

1889.84.text:
I will go even further.
Provided they have the support of the local

1893.87.text:
business community, these mayors will be able
to add a premium to the rates to pay for new

1898.80.text:
infrastructure and build for their cities’
future.

1902.50.text:
Yes, further savings to be made in local government,
but radical reform too.

1907.75.text:
So an end to the uniform business rate.
Money raised locally, spent locally.

1912.83.text:
Every council able to cut business taxes.
Every mayor able to build for their city’s

1917.64.text:
future.
A new way to govern our country.

1920.45.text:
Power to the people.
Let the devolution revolution begin.

1932.36.text:
Friends, the great mistake for this country
would be to stop moving forward.

1945.53.text:
To fail to take the big decisions.
To coast when we should be decisive.

1950.14.text:
Those were the clear instructions we were
given by the British people five months ago.

1954.89.text:
That’s the job we’ve been asked to do.
We live in this great prosperous, peaceful,

1960.26.text:
political democracy.
Precisely because those who came before us

1964.33.text:
did their job.
Because they established factories and built

1967.72.text:
cathedrals and laid railways.
Because they conducted experiments and made

1971.71.text:
scientific breakthroughs and conquered disease.
Because they compiled encyclopaedias, wrote

1976.86.text:
poetry and invented computers.
Because they set sail from these lands, fought

1981.59.text:
tyrants and opened Britain to the world.
Now it is our turn.

1985.91.text:
We have inherited their legacy but also their
responsibilities.

1989.82.text:
We have learned from their great deeds and
also from their mistakes.

1993.20.text:
We see all the things they have done.
And we see all the things that are yet to

1999.40.text:
… we accept this responsibility.
We will take on these challenges.

2003.21.text:
We will do our duty.
Some people stand on the sidelines.

2007.38.text:
Some want to knock things down.
We are the builders.
